answers.answer: My first question would be if they treat by labs only or by a combination of labs and symptoms.  That's a biggie.  If they treat by labs only, then start looking for endo #4.Do they specialize in thyroid disease or is their practice focused on diabetes or other endocrine diseases?  That's another biggie.Since you have experience in this area, ask how they communicate with patients.  Does the dr call or do they have the nurses do it?  Do they call you with test results or do they make you wait a month or two until your next appt to get them?  Do they offer copies of your test paperwork, gladly give you copies when you ask, or do you have to fight for it?Ask what tests they normally run.  Most will just run the standard TSH, FT4 and antibodies.  You know you've got a keeper if they run TSH, FT4, FT3, antibodies, along with a full nutritional panel including ferritin, Bvits and D.  I mention the nutritional panel because so many thyroid folks also have nutritional deficiencies.  Not like that's a secret, although many docs won't even consider it.  I'd especially focus on the Bvits because, in another one of your posts, it sounds like you might have a deficiency by the symptoms you were talking about.Do they offer options for treatment?  How do they feel about alternative treatments and/or nutritional supplements?  Of course, that's more of a biggie for me rather than most people, but its something to think about and lets you know how open-minded they'd be to your questions.How much time do they spend with each patient?  The StupidEndo I was seeing scheduled her appts 15 minutes apart, whether it was a new patient visit or not.That's all I can think of for now.  Of course, a good part of this is also going by feel, but the questions help.  Good luck and lets hope this one is a keeper! :)

I meet endo #3.    She seems promising-spent about 1 hr 15 minutes w/me.   told me i'm in a place where i need frequent contact and she'll see me every 4 weeks right now while i try to feel better.      she ordered TSH, FT4, FT3, thyroglobulin but not a full nutritional panel.    also added blood sugar since my levels have been a bit elevated.   i did ask her about deficiencies after seeing how many people on this board have them, but she said it would be rare for someone my age to have any.   although, i have to say, since i started beefing up the B-complex, i'm feeling much better .    her practice is diabetes and thyroid, but she has a LOT of experience w/thyroid.   she's different from endo #2 in her RAI protocol, which makes me nervous...she's by the book .  2 years in a row of withdrawal.
